sections.MISSION:
Comanche conducts GTA 500 NLT 100019JUN2024 on the Grafenwöhr Training Area in order to build driver proficiency and to stress test vehicles for Troop STX
Commander’s
sections.PURPOSE: of this is to identify any faults with Comanche Troop's vehicles.​
sections.KEY TASKS:
PCC/PCI/PMCS License and Dispatch book inspection Safety and Recovery Equipment checks COMMEX
Complete two laps around GTA
Communicate on move via SINGARS
Execute wash rack operations
sections.END STATE:
Training: Drivers proficiency, Leaders proficiency, Comms on move reporting
Equipment: Test all equipment, all deficiencies annotated on 5988’s and verified by mechanics
Training Objectives
Identify Commex issues
Build drivers confidence
Stress test vehicles
Resourcing
OIC: LT Conner NCOIC: SSG Bullard
POC: LT Grant Conner; grant.t.conner.mil@army.mil
COA: 12 1300 JUN 2024
1/2 CR MP
staging
GTA 500 Macro Route
The movement will be conducted at the platoon level. The order of movement will be 1st, 2nd, then 3rd. Once the lead platoon reaches CP 1, the following Platoon will begin movement. On the second lap, the platoon will stop at the wash station at Grafenwohr before continuing back to the motor pool.

draw.mission_task_and_description: Mortar PLT executes GTA 500; a drivers training opportunity around GTA and COMMEX on 17 April 2024 IOT create convoy procedure proficiency and stress test vehicles in preparation for Troop STX.

values: Drivers/VCs adhere to posted speed limits.
Drivers are licensed.
Vehicles are dispatched and PMCS'd.
Vehicles drive the route prior to iterations with any other maneuvering element on the range
All soldiers in tactical vehicles will be seated in a designated seating platform or standing with a restraint harness.
Leaders understand the real-world CASEVAC/MEDEVAC plan and brief subordinates on it.
Tactical vehicles use a ground guide when maneuvering within parking/assembly areas off the range.
SLs accurately report front-line trace to their vehicle, coordinate movements with VC.
Drivers exercise caution driving under blackout conditions.

-Safety brief, rehearsals, PCC/PCI, Medical Concept of Support dissemination. -PCC/PCI of vehicle restraints prior to SP -Reduce speed during limited visibility (includes dust and fog) - Convoy brief executed IAW SQDN TACSOP prior to all movements to and from the TA. -PLT leadership inspect drivers licenses, vehicle dispatches, 5988s
OIC, RSO, safeties, VCs, drivers, squad leaders.

subtasks.hazard: Hazardous road conditions (Inclement weather, uneven roads, etc.)

values: Drivers/VCs adhere to posted speed limits.
Vehicle maneuvers limited to predetermined routes on GTA
Leaders execute deliberate range reconnaissance and identify possible dangerous areas.
Vehicles will reduce speed in the event of hazardous road conditions.
-Safety brief, rehearsals, PCC/PCI, weather checks before/during LFX execution.
OIC, RSO, safeties, VCs, drivers, squad leaders.
Soldiers execute drivers training are in full Dragoon Standard.
Soldiers climbing on top of vehicles will wear helmets and maintain three points of contact.
No unharnessed Soldiers when vehicles are moving.
Medics are on hand, in designated MEDEVAC vehicle, and ready to respond during iterations.
MEDEVAC vehicle will meet all GTA requirements (marked in 4 locations, ability to lay litter flat).
Safety brief, CONOP distribution, coordination with Medics. Ramp Brief
OIC, RSO, Medics, leaders.
Sensitive items accounted for prior to and following each iteration.
All sensitive items tied down IAW SOP.
Sensitive Item inventory conducted following training IAW Squadron Recovery SOP.
-Leader involvement, inventories, thorough PCC/PCIs. Ramp Brief
Leaders at all levels, soldiers.
Range will cease fire if wildlife is identified on range or a fire begins.
All soldiers understand roles as safeties.
Firefighting detail on hand and prepared to respond.
Consistent communications with Range Control/Range Meister in the event of a wildlife intrusion or a fire.
Approval of any necessary FIRECON memos.
Safety brief, range orientation. Ramp Brief
OIC, RSO, participating soldiers.
If communications are lost, Serial OIC's will utilize PACE plan (TSM, ATAK Chat, FM, vehicle flags).
OIC/RSO preparation, Ramp Brief
OIC, RSO.
Speed limit is based on the following: Road Conditions, Vehicle Type and Visibility.
Normal Driving Conditions:
On paved portions of the main tank trails: 60 KPH (36 MPH)
On gravel portions of the main tank trails: 50 KPH (30 MPH)
Range roads: 30 KPH (18 MPH)
When passing troops: 16 KPH (10 MPH)
Limited Visibility/Inclement weather Driving Conditions:
RSO, OIC, 7ATC Safety Office, and GTA Range Operations may reduce speed limits.
Built up areas: All vehicles reduce speed to 10 MPH when approaching, entering, or
driving in/around built up areas.
In all cases where there is a speed limit sign or other posted instructions – obey the posted
limit and / or sign.
RSOs understand the range, participate in setup, and conduct COG Risk Mitigation Brief as needed
RSOs brief all Range Cadre and Training Support Personnel the risks on their range
-Obey posted speed limit signs. -Ramp Briefs -Follow GTA SOP #1 -Unit SOPs
-Vehicle commanders and operators - Safeties - RSO, OIC

draw.overall_supervision_plan: I assess the overall initial risk to be medium as a result of an unlikely probability of a catastrophic event; I assess the overall residual risk to be low due to an seldom probability of a moderate event.Most Dangerous Risk: Rollover/ Loss of vehicular controlMitigation: Drivers will strictly adhere to speed limits, road signs, and road conditions based on Platoon Leader/ Platoon Sergeant guidance Most Likely Risk: Loss of comm's during TRMMitigation: Having a 100% up on TSM, FM, TAK chat, and Host nation cell before SP'ing. Identifying and trouble shooting issues during COMMEX, all soldiers understanding the PACE plan, and the lead vehicle will slow down to eliminate any potential breaks in contact during the TRM.
